thread.title: It's Renshaw v Khawaja for a spot in opening India Test
thread.title_full: It's Renshaw v Khawaja for a spot in opening India Test

title: It's Renshaw v Khawaja for a spot in opening India Test
text:
Map: India 
Matt Renshaw and Usman Khawaja are locked in a tight selection showdown for the final top-order spot up for grabs in the Australian XI to face India. 
With the first Test starting in Pune on Thursday, coach Darren Lehmann and chairman of selectors Trevor Hohns will likely only have one decision to make, providing there are no shocks. 
Shaun and Mitch Marsh, who both performed well in Australia's tour game against India A , are set to make simultaneous returns in the four-Test series opener. 
That would mean either Renshaw or Khawaja misses out. 
"It's a tight call between probably [Renshaw] and Usman, I would think," Lehmann said. 
"We'll have to make that decision when we get closer to the Test. 
"We're pretty settled on what we want, but â€¦ we need to wait until we get there and see the wicket." 
Renshaw scored 184 in his most recent Test at the SCG and is now regarded by Hohns' panel as David Warner's long-term partner. 
Khawaja, who was the leading run-scorer in the recent Test series between Australia and South Africa, looked brilliant during the home summer and is yet to be given a chance to shine on the subcontinent since being axed in Sri Lanka last year. 
Renshaw was picked ahead of Khawaja in the drawn three-day game at Mumbai's Brabourne Stadium, but scored a total of 21 runs from his two knocks. 
Shaun Marsh opened in his previous two Tests, notably scoring 130 in Colombo during Australia's 3-0 series loss in Sri Lanka, but Lehmann said it was more likely he and skipper Steve Smith "would float between three and four". Photo: Shaun Marsh's tour-match ton basically guaranteed another Test cap. (AP: Rajanish Kakade) 
Neither Marsh brother has played a Test since the first match of the home summer against the Proteas. 
Shaun Marsh retired after reaching three figures in Mumbai, while Mitch Marsh opened the bowling and scored a measured 75 in the first-class match. 
"He batted really well for us in Sri Lanka to be fair, he was one of our better batters," Lehmann said of Mitch Marsh. 
"We've been impressed with way he plays spin bowling." 
Nathan Lyon went for 5.6 runs an over in Mumbai but claimed four wickets, while Steve O'Keefe grabbed figures of 3-103. 
"I'm pleased with the way the spinners are going," Lehmann said. 
"It's going to be a challenge bowling here, but they're on the right path." 
AAP
